Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Torsion Adapter Versus Rigid Adapter in Unilateral Transtibial Amputees

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial involved 10 unilateral transtibial amputees who were randomly assigned to wear either a torsion or rigid adapter in a crossover design.

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to wear either a torsion or rigid adapter

Method_Outcome.evidence: Functional mobility was evaluated using an activity monitor and a 6-minute walk test with turns.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial involved 10 unilateral transtibial amputees

Result_Outcome.evidence: Participants wearing a torsion adapter took more low- and medium-intensity steps per day (331 ± 365 and 437 ± 511 difference in steps; effect size = 0.44 and 0.17; CI, 70–592 and 71–802; p = 0.019 and 0.024, respectively) and reported less pain interference (1.9 ± 1.7 change in score; effect size = 0.83; CI, 0.3–3.4; p = 0.026).
